normalised: So, someone asked me about planning a trip to India, specifically about the challenges of booking hotels and figuring out addresses. It reminded me of my own initial struggles when I first started travelling extensively within the country. Thought I’d share some hard-earned wisdom!

normalised: The biggest issue I faced was deciphering Indian addresses. They're not always as straightforward as, say, in the U-S or the U-K. You see something like "House Number twelve divided by three, fourth Lane, Near Hanuman Temple, Ameerpet, Hyderabad - five hundred thousand and sixteen" and your G-P-S just throws its hands up! And that's a relatively simple one!

normalised: My first major travel snafu happened in Bangalore. I’d booked a hotel near M-G Road, specifically noting down "hash thirty two, Barton Centre, M-G Road, Bangalore, Karnataka, five hundred sixty thousand and one" as the address. Easy enough, right? Wrong! The auto-rickshaw driver took me to the *wrong* Barton Centre. Turns out, Bangalore has more than one… who knew? After about an hour of frantic phone calls and escalating frustration (and a lot of extra rupees spent on the auto), I finally managed to find the right place. Apparently, I should have also mentioned it was *opposite* the Metro station or the "next to Citibank A-T-M" detail I found later on Google. Lesson learned: always confirm landmarks!

normalised: Then there was the time in Jaipur. The hotel confirmation email stated, "Hotel Raj Mahal, C dash two, M-I Road, Jaipur, Rajasthan, three hundred two thousand and one." Sounds precise, but M-I Road is long! And “C dash two” could be anything. The only way I finally located it was by calling the hotel and asking for *nearby* landmarks. "Near the petrol pump after Panch Batti circle," they said. That did the trick.

normalised: Another trick I learned is to ALWAYS double-check the pin code. A typo can land you miles away, especially in sprawling cities like Delhi or Mumbai. Imagine ending up in the wrong *sector* in Gurgaon! One time, I almost got sent to a completely different part of Chennai because the last digit of the pincode was off by "one" ... six hundred thousand and one instead of six hundred thousand and two, I think it was.

normalised: And online booking? Don't blindly trust the addresses listed on travel websites. Verify them. Call the hotel directly. Confirm the landmarks. Ask for directions in *local* terms. A G-P-S might not understand “opposite Corporation Bank,” but a local will. Also, learn some basic Hindi or the local language. Knowing "paas mein" (nearby) and "seedha jao" (go straight) can be lifesavers.
